intro: Amomum lappaceum, commonly known as the mountain cardamom, is a tropical perennial plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the ginger family (Zingiberaceae) and is characterized by its aromatic, lance-shaped leaves and clustered, fragrant flowers. The plant produces small, three-lobed fruits that contain numerous black seeds, which are used in traditional medicine and as a spice. Amomum lappaceum thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often cultivated for its medicinal properties and aromatic value. Its botanical features make it an important species in both horticulture and pharmacology.
